overview.name: Resume
overview.description: Facebook to create resumes, called “work histories” feature Share privately while applying for jobs on facebook Can either submit own resume or use facebook feature Includes period of time you worked in a job and contact information Can make public or visible to who you chose Resume can help target potential jobs

overview.name:
GenPact (outsourcing firm)
Locations Globally
overview.description:
Facebook uses content moderation to ensure consumers have a positive experience, and so they can filter out the harmful content from the good. Often content moderators are stationed across the world in 3rd party outsourcing companies, often referred to as “click farms.” Content moderators are told to keep quiet about their work and sign a disclosure agreement that puts their job at risk and get treated with a fine if they tell others what they are up to. Recently, more light shined on to these behaviors of the outsourcing industry and the labor that these employees perform. Employees are often improperly trained and paid in these positions and leave with mental trauma from the pictures displayed on the screen in front of them.

Genpact is a global outsourcing firm that censors facebooks media. Genpact as a whole has 10,000 content moderators around the globe and supports more than 30 languages. Genpact has a 1,600 member team in an outsourcing firm in southern India city; here, each content moderator views 2,000- 25,000 posts a day while they work their 8-hour shifts; according to the Economic Times, Genpact won a contract with Facebook last year to provide content moderations. Genpact primarily is hiring content moderators who speak Indian languages, such as Tamil and Punjabi. In 2019, Genpact reviews complaints from 7 various content moderators saying that their work was underpaid, stressful, and traumatic, but Genpact declined the comment. Genpact has many content moderatos located around the world, according to facebook, these conderators would sensor pornography, terrorism, self-harm, and much more. Facebook explained how they assign “specially trained teams” to each unit, but affording to employees they are not prepared for the content they see on their day-to-day. On the Genpact website, they explain how they us “augmented intelligence to protect online communities,” meaning they use humans to protect online communities while mixing AI-powered analytics.

location.address: Guadalajara: Avenida Acueducto 6075 A, Puerta de Hierro, Zapopan, Jalisco, México

overview.name:
GenPact (outsourcing firm)
Locations Globally
overview.description:
Facebook uses content moderation to ensure consumers have a positive experience, and so they can filter out the harmful content from the good. Often content moderators are stationed across the world in 3rd party outsourcing companies, often referred to as “click farms.” Content moderators are told to keep quiet about their work and sign a disclosure agreement that puts their job at risk and get treated with a fine if they tell others what they are up to. Recently, more light shined on to these behaviors of the outsourcing industry and the labor that these employees perform. Employees are often improperly trained and paid in these positions and leave with mental trauma from the pictures displayed on the screen in front of them.

Genpact is a global outsourcing firm that censors facebooks media. Genpact as a whole has 10,000 content moderators around the globe and supports more than 30 languages. Genpact has a 1,600 member team in an outsourcing firm in southern India city; here, each content moderator views 2,000- 25,000 posts a day while they work their 8-hour shifts; according to the Economic Times, Genpact won a contract with Facebook last year to provide content moderations. Genpact primarily is hiring content moderators who speak Indian languages, such as Tamil and Punjabi. In 2019, Genpact reviews complaints from 7 various content moderators saying that their work was underpaid, stressful, and traumatic, but Genpact declined the comment. Genpact has many content moderatos located around the world, according to facebook, these conderators would sensor pornography, terrorism, self-harm, and much more. Facebook explained how they assign “specially trained teams” to each unit, but affording to employees they are not prepared for the content they see on their day-to-day. On the Genpact website, they explain how they us “augmented intelligence to protect online communities,” meaning they use humans to protect online communities while mixing AI-powered analytics.

overview.name: Accenture
overview.description: Accenture uses a synergistic artificial intelligence relationship. Thes locations where provided by Accenture, explaining where content modators are located around the world. Although Accentue privided these locations; Accenture and other third-party companies will not confirm how many countries host these sites. Accenture focuses on a relationship between humans and AL when censoring content. Accenture has more thanthan 459,000 people working in 40 industries in more than120 countries. In the comapmies birchure, they only mentioned the location plotted when talking about content moderation, it is likely that there are more content moderators located in other parts of the world whom still work for this company. Accenture oversees some of the 400 million photos that are uploaded to Facebook daily. To take away the issues that have surrounded content moderators' lives and the pushback facebook has gained surrounding this issue, Accenture put forward a new plan that uses AL tools but still providing those jobs to a substantial amount moderators around the world.

overview.name: Arvato
overview.description: Arvato is one of Facebook's third-party content moderation outsourcing providers. These desitnations are the offices and locations that Arvato provided on thier website, depticting where thier offices are located. Arvato has 70,000 employees in more than 40 countries and has provided Facebook with content moderation services since 2015. It is a german company that aids Facebook computer services. Facebook is one of Arvato's largest clients but stays silent surronding content moderation. It is clear that Arvato removes harmful content on Facebook, but there is little to nothing surrounding Facebook's interactions with this company. Employees' accounts mention that there were moderators worldwide, and employees were advised not to tell anyone what they were doing for the company. They explained that the company did not adequately train their employees and, due to the secretive surrounding these issues, did not feel as if they had a voice. Experts suggest that about 100,000 people are working as content moderators worldwide from external services provided such as Arvato.

overview.name: CPL
overview.description: CPL is an international IT recruitment company, which provides outsourcing for Facebook to regulate content. CPL's website states, "CPL's RPO solutions offer your business agility, market expertise, access to transformational technologies and best practice honed through 20 years of experience, so you can focus on other core areas of your business and respond to the fluctuating economic climate." CPL offers Selective RPO, one of the RPO solutions they provide; selective RPO is CPL's "Selective offering allows you to choose the support your company needs. Simply choose the part or parts of the recruitment process you need to outsource, and we'll provide the best solutions. Examples of past Selective RPO solutions include sourcing and screening, onboarding or pipeline, and candidate assessments. This solution is really successful at supporting volume or niche hiring." ((https://www.cpl.com/ie/for-clients/cpl-services/talent-solutions-services/enterprise-solutions/recruitment-process-outsourcing-rpo). Anna Heraty played a significant role in the companies success; she was awarded as a pioneering entrepreneur because of her ability to locate and fill the positions of content moderators in Ireland. CPL moderates for big Social Media Companies, including; Facebook, Google, and TikTok. Despite CPL's success in this market, they have received backlash due to Facebook's moderators' work conditions on the job. According to The Guardian, CPL's Facebook content moderators were "forced" to work in the Dublin office, although the "high tier lockdown" was in place due to Covid-19 guidelines, while Facebook's workers worked from home. "A CPL spokesperson said: 'Our employees carry out extremely important work, keeping the Facebook platform safe. They are positively contributing to society in the work they do in ensuring the safety of our online communities, and their roles are deemed essential. Due to the nature of the work, it cannot be carried out from home'" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/18/facebook-content-moderators-urge-mark-zuckerberg-to-let-them-work-remotely.htm). A moderator at CPL said, "'We want the same rights and protections as Facebook employees. The way Facebook organizes this work feels discriminatory and unfair. Facebook is one of the world's richest companies, yet Facebook asks us to risk our life, to come into work, and keep Facebook safe and profitable. Why can't they afford to hire us?"' (https://www.thenationalnews.com/world/backlash-at-facebook-s-outsourcing-firms-policing-social-media-1.1173158) Over the past year, more than 200 moderators informed Facebook about their concerns surrounding the current pandemic. Facebook came back and said that the content is too graphic to be viewed from home. CNBC published a report by Sam Shead on November 12th, 2020, titled, "TikTok is luring Facebook moderators to fill new trust and safety hubs" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/12/tiktok-luring-facebook-content-moderators.html). In this article, Shead explains how "many content moderators who work at outsourcing firms like Accenture, CPL, Hays, and Voxpro have been leaving to take in-house roles at TikTok, according to LinkedIn analysis by CNBC." These firms are "under contract with Facebook." According to the same source, Chirs gray, a 54-year-old man based in Dublin, worked for CPL for ten mounts. Gray said he had to deal with "nasty stuff" and explained the horrific content he saw while shuffling through 100 pieces of reported content an hour. While working the night shift at CPL. According to CNBC he, "was paid 12 euros 98 cents ($15.39) up until 8 p.m., when the pay went up 25%. "That's not a lot of money," he said, adding that Dublin is one of the most expensive cities in Europe. Employees were fed food that had been shipped in from the nearby Facebook office and reheated, said Gray, who worked at CPL from June 2017 to April 2018." Grey is not the only one who has experienced this, "Dozens of contractors from across the EU that is in the process of using Facebook and CPL for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)." He explains that Face book has been "willfully blind to what was going on" and did not care for its people. Face book now provides 24-hour on-site counseling, "in order for outsourcing companies to do Facebook content moderating."

location.address: 1 Grand Canal Square, Grand Canal Harbour, Dublin 2, Ireland

According to CNBC he, "was paid 12 euros 98 cents ($15.39) up until 8 p.m., when the pay went up 25%. "That's not a lot of money," he said, adding that Dublin is one of the most expensive cities in Europe. Employees were fed food that had been shipped in from the nearby Facebook office and reheated, said Gray, who worked at CPL from June 2017 to April 2018." Grey is not the only one who has experienced this, "Dozens of contractors from across the EU that is in the process of using Facebook and CPL for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)." He explains that Face book has been "willfully blind to what was going on" and did not care for its people. Face book now provides 24-hour on-site counseling, "in order for outsourcing companies to do Facebook content moderating."

overview.name: CPL
overview.description: CPL is an international IT recruitment company, which provides outsourcing for Facebook to regulate content. CPL's website states, "CPL's RPO solutions offer your business agility, market expertise, access to transformational technologies and best practice honed through 20 years of experience, so you can focus on other core areas of your business and respond to the fluctuating economic climate." CPL offers Selective RPO, one of the RPO solutions they provide; selective RPO is CPL's "Selective offering allows you to choose the support your company needs. Simply choose the part or parts of the recruitment process you need to outsource, and we'll provide the best solutions. Examples of past Selective RPO solutions include sourcing and screening, onboarding or pipeline, and candidate assessments. This solution is really successful at supporting volume or niche hiring." ((https://www.cpl.com/ie/for-clients/cpl-services/talent-solutions-services/enterprise-solutions/recruitment-process-outsourcing-rpo). Anna Heraty played a significant role in the companies success; she was awarded as a pioneering entrepreneur because of her ability to locate and fill the positions of content moderators in Ireland. CPL moderates for big Social Media Companies, including; Facebook, Google, and TikTok. Despite CPL's success in this market, they have received backlash due to Facebook's moderators' work conditions on the job. According to The Guardian, CPL's Facebook content moderators were "forced" to work in the Dublin office, although the "high tier lockdown" was in place due to Covid-19 guidelines, while Facebook's workers worked from home. "A CPL spokesperson said: 'Our employees carry out extremely important work, keeping the Facebook platform safe. They are positively contributing to society in the work they do in ensuring the safety of our online communities, and their roles are deemed essential. Due to the nature of the work, it cannot be carried out from home'" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/18/facebook-content-moderators-urge-mark-zuckerberg-to-let-them-work-remotely.htm). A moderator at CPL said, "'We want the same rights and protections as Facebook employees. The way Facebook organizes this work feels discriminatory and unfair. Facebook is one of the world's richest companies, yet Facebook asks us to risk our life, to come into work, and keep Facebook safe and profitable. Why can't they afford to hire us?"' (https://www.thenationalnews.com/world/backlash-at-facebook-s-outsourcing-firms-policing-social-media-1.1173158) Over the past year, more than 200 moderators informed Facebook about their concerns surrounding the current pandemic. Facebook came back and said that the content is too graphic to be viewed from home. CNBC published a report by Sam Shead on November 12th, 2020, titled, "TikTok is luring Facebook moderators to fill new trust and safety hubs" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/12/tiktok-luring-facebook-content-moderators.html). In this article, Shead explains how "many content moderators who work at outsourcing firms like Accenture, CPL, Hays, and Voxpro have been leaving to take in-house roles at TikTok, according to LinkedIn analysis by CNBC." These firms are "under contract with Facebook." According to the same source, Chirs gray, a 54-year-old man based in Dublin, worked for CPL for ten mounts. Gray said he had to deal with "nasty stuff" and explained the horrific content he saw while shuffling through 100 pieces of reported content an hour. While working the night shift at CPL. According to CNBC he, "was paid 12 euros 98 cents ($15.39) up until 8 p.m., when the pay went up 25%. "That's not a lot of money," he said, adding that Dublin is one of the most expensive cities in Europe. Employees were fed food that had been shipped in from the nearby Facebook office and reheated, said Gray, who worked at CPL from June 2017 to April 2018." Grey is not the only one who has experienced this, "Dozens of contractors from across the EU that is in the process of using Facebook and CPL for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)." He explains that Face book has been "willfully blind to what was going on" and did not care for its people. Face book now provides 24-hour on-site counseling, "in order for outsourcing companies to do Facebook content moderating."

CPL offers Selective RPO, one of the RPO solutions they provide; selective RPO is CPL's "Selective offering allows you to choose the support your company needs. Simply choose the part or parts of the recruitment process you need to outsource, and we'll provide the best solutions. Examples of past Selective RPO solutions include sourcing and screening, onboarding or pipeline, and candidate assessments. This solution is really successful at supporting volume or niche hiring." ((https://www.cpl.com/ie/for-clients/cpl-services/talent-solutions-services/enterprise-solutions/recruitment-process-outsourcing-rpo). Anna Heraty played a significant role in the companies success; she was awarded as a pioneering entrepreneur because of her ability to locate and fill the positions of content moderators in Ireland. CPL moderates for big Social Media Companies, including; Facebook, Google, and TikTok. Despite CPL's success in this market, they have received backlash due to Facebook's moderators' work conditions on the job. According to The Guardian, CPL's Facebook content moderators were "forced" to work in the Dublin office, although the "high tier lockdown" was in place due to Covid-19 guidelines, while Facebook's workers worked from home. "A CPL spokesperson said: 'Our employees carry out extremely important work, keeping the Facebook platform safe. They are positively contributing to society in the work they do in ensuring the safety of our online communities, and their roles are deemed essential. Due to the nature of the work, it cannot be carried out from home'" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/18/facebook-content-moderators-urge-mark-zuckerberg-to-let-them-work-remotely.htm). A moderator at CPL said, "'We want the same rights and protections as Facebook employees. The way Facebook organizes this work feels discriminatory and unfair. Facebook is one of the world's richest companies, yet Facebook asks us to risk our life, to come into work, and keep Facebook safe and profitable. Why can't they afford to hire us?"' (https://www.thenationalnews.com/world/backlash-at-facebook-s-outsourcing-firms-policing-social-media-1.1173158) Over the past year, more than 200 moderators informed Facebook about their concerns surrounding the current pandemic. Facebook came back and said that the content is too graphic to be viewed from home. CNBC published a report by Sam Shead on November 12th, 2020, titled, "TikTok is luring Facebook moderators to fill new trust and safety hubs" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/12/tiktok-luring-facebook-content-moderators.html). In this article, Shead explains how "many content moderators who work at outsourcing firms like Accenture, CPL, Hays, and Voxpro have been leaving to take in-house roles at TikTok, according to LinkedIn analysis by CNBC." These firms are "under contract with Facebook." According to the same source, Chirs gray, a 54-year-old man based in Dublin, worked for CPL for ten mounts. Gray said he had to deal with "nasty stuff" and explained the horrific content he saw while shuffling through 100 pieces of reported content an hour. While working the night shift at CPL. According to CNBC he, "was paid 12 euros 98 cents ($15.39) up until 8 p.m., when the pay went up 25%. "That's not a lot of money," he said, adding that Dublin is one of the most expensive cities in Europe. Employees were fed food that had been shipped in from the nearby Facebook office and reheated, said Gray, who worked at CPL from June 2017 to April 2018." Grey is not the only one who has experienced this, "Dozens of contractors from across the EU that is in the process of using Facebook and CPL for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)." He explains that Face book has been "willfully blind to what was going on" and did not care for its people. Face book now provides 24-hour on-site counseling, "in order for outsourcing companies to do Facebook content moderating."

According to The Guardian, CPL's Facebook content moderators were "forced" to work in the Dublin office, although the "high tier lockdown" was in place due to Covid-19 guidelines, while Facebook's workers worked from home. "A CPL spokesperson said: 'Our employees carry out extremely important work, keeping the Facebook platform safe. They are positively contributing to society in the work they do in ensuring the safety of our online communities, and their roles are deemed essential. Due to the nature of the work, it cannot be carried out from home'" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/18/facebook-content-moderators-urge-mark-zuckerberg-to-let-them-work-remotely.htm). A moderator at CPL said, "'We want the same rights and protections as Facebook employees. The way Facebook organizes this work feels discriminatory and unfair. Facebook is one of the world's richest companies, yet Facebook asks us to risk our life, to come into work, and keep Facebook safe and profitable. Why can't they afford to hire us?"' (https://www.thenationalnews.com/world/backlash-at-facebook-s-outsourcing-firms-policing-social-media-1.1173158) Over the past year, more than 200 moderators informed Facebook about their concerns surrounding the current pandemic. Facebook came back and said that the content is too graphic to be viewed from home. CNBC published a report by Sam Shead on November 12th, 2020, titled, "TikTok is luring Facebook moderators to fill new trust and safety hubs" (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/12/tiktok-luring-facebook-content-moderators.html). In this article, Shead explains how "many content moderators who work at outsourcing firms like Accenture, CPL, Hays, and Voxpro have been leaving to take in-house roles at TikTok, according to LinkedIn analysis by CNBC." These firms are "under contract with Facebook." According to the same source, Chirs gray, a 54-year-old man based in Dublin, worked for CPL for ten mounts. Gray said he had to deal with "nasty stuff" and explained the horrific content he saw while shuffling through 100 pieces of reported content an hour. While working the night shift at CPL. According to CNBC he, "was paid 12 euros 98 cents ($15.39) up until 8 p.m., when the pay went up 25%. "That's not a lot of money," he said, adding that Dublin is one of the most expensive cities in Europe. Employees were fed food that had been shipped in from the nearby Facebook office and reheated, said Gray, who worked at CPL from June 2017 to April 2018." Grey is not the only one who has experienced this, "Dozens of contractors from across the EU that is in the process of using Facebook and CPL for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)." He explains that Face book has been "willfully blind to what was going on" and did not care for its people. Face book now provides 24-hour on-site counseling, "in order for outsourcing companies to do Facebook content moderating."

overview.name: Pro Unlimited, Inc.
overview.description: The contractor Pro Unlimited, Inc. helps Facebook manage and locate temporary employees to work as content moderators. In 2017, Facebook was sued due to the PDST an employee developed due to her exposed content. The lawsuit did not focus on the details about the job; instead, it focused on how content moderators work; the victim explained that she did not want Facebook to "retaliate against her using a purported non-disclosure agreement." Due to the lack of information surrounding the locations of the moderators, the map explains where Pro Unlimited has offices around the world. On Pro Unlimited's website, they suggest going to a different website (https://prounlimited.com/icn/faq_overview.html) to access all information about the contacting they do in one location. There is no mention of content moderation, just about the "Independent contractor Neighborhood." Pro Unlimited has 20 Corporate Family Connections with 13 subsidiaries and six branches, with Pro Unlimited standing as the "Ultimate Parent," making the global destinations of content moderators extremely challenging to find. Without the lawsuit against Facebook, ProUnlimited could have kept secrecy surrounding content moderation for longer.

overview.name: Cognizant
overview.description: Cognizant is a professional services firm. Cognizant is ranked 194 on the Fortune 500 list and is one of the worlds leading professional service companies. Cognizant has many locations globally, they where ranked #533 in Forbes Global 2000 in May 2000. Cognizant used to be Facebook’s leading company for regulating content. Cognizant signed a contract with Facebook to enforces facebooks policies, making their workers sign a nondisclosure agreement.Three former North American workers at Cognizant broke this agreement and spoke up about the conditions of the work site and the trama they face in their daily lives due to the job. This exploitation of workers and the media surrounding content moderation impacted Facebook and Cognizant in the 2019. Following these accusations in 2019, Cognizant CEO Brain Humphries announce that they will be moving away from content moderation because it does not fit with in the companies “strategic vision.” This move away from content moderation, other companies such as GenPact, Accenture, and Wipro will benefit profoundly. Cognizant stopped providing services to Facebook in terms of monitoring user content and opened up $250 million a year opportunity for other companies focusing on content regulation. Although the reason for the move is unknown, analyst suggest that the nature of moderation work might contribute to the companies “well-time” exit. Cognizant cut as many as 7,000 jobs due to their exit of content moderation, impacting another 6,000 employees world wide. Cognizant said they would remove 10,000-12,000 employees and “resell and redeploy” about 5,000 of those impacted.” Which was the perfect opportunity for other moderation business to pick up more moderators globally. Company executives said, "Exiting this area will impact an additional approximately 6,000 roles worldwide, though the company intends to work with its partners to explore ways to transition the roles to alternative vendors, thereby reducing the impact to associates”(Mendonca, J, https://colorado.idm.oclc.org/login?url=https://www-proquest-com.colorado.idm.oclc.org/newspapers/cognizant-cut-7000-mid-senior-level-jobs-exit/docview/2310750784/se-2?accountid=14503).

Cognizant signed a contract with Facebook to enforces facebooks policies, making their workers sign a nondisclosure agreement.Three former North American workers at Cognizant broke this agreement and spoke up about the conditions of the work site and the trama they face in their daily lives due to the job. This exploitation of workers and the media surrounding content moderation impacted Facebook and Cognizant in the 2019. Following these accusations in 2019, Cognizant CEO Brain Humphries announce that they will be moving away from content moderation because it does not fit with in the companies “strategic vision.” This move away from content moderation, other companies such as GenPact, Accenture, and Wipro will benefit profoundly. Cognizant stopped providing services to Facebook in terms of monitoring user content and opened up $250 million a year opportunity for other companies focusing on content regulation. Although the reason for the move is unknown, analyst suggest that the nature of moderation work might contribute to the companies “well-time” exit. Cognizant cut as many as 7,000 jobs due to their exit of content moderation, impacting another 6,000 employees world wide. Cognizant said they would remove 10,000-12,000 employees and “resell and redeploy” about 5,000 of those impacted.” Which was the perfect opportunity for other moderation business to pick up more moderators globally. Company executives said, "Exiting this area will impact an additional approximately 6,000 roles worldwide, though the company intends to work with its partners to explore ways to transition the roles to alternative vendors, thereby reducing the impact to associates”(Mendonca, J, https://colorado.idm.oclc.org/login?url=https://www-proquest-com.colorado.idm.oclc.org/newspapers/cognizant-cut-7000-mid-senior-level-jobs-exit/docview/2310750784/se-2?accountid=14503).

Company executives said, "Exiting this area will impact an additional approximately 6,000 roles worldwide, though the company intends to work with its partners to explore ways to transition the roles to alternative vendors, thereby reducing the impact to associates”(Mendonca, J, https://colorado.idm.oclc.org/login?url=https://www-proquest-com.colorado.idm.oclc.org/newspapers/cognizant-cut-7000-mid-senior-level-jobs-exit/docview/2310750784/se-2?accountid=14503).

overview.name: Cognizant
overview.description: Cognizant is a professional services firm. Cognizant is ranked 194 on the Fortune 500 list and is one of the worlds leading professional service companies. Cognizant has many locations globally, they where ranked #533 in Forbes Global 2000 in May 2000. Cognizant used to be Facebook’s leading company for regulating content. Cognizant signed a contract with Facebook to enforces facebooks policies, making their workers sign a nondisclosure agreement.Three former North American workers at Cognizant broke this agreement and spoke up about the conditions of the work site and the trama they face in their daily lives due to the job. This exploitation of workers and the media surrounding content moderation impacted Facebook and Cognizant in the 2019. Following these accusations in 2019, Cognizant CEO Brain Humphries announce that they will be moving away from content moderation because it does not fit with in the companies “strategic vision.” This move away from content moderation, other companies such as GenPact, Accenture, and Wipro will benefit profoundly. Cognizant stopped providing services to Facebook in terms of monitoring user content and opened up $250 million a year opportunity for other companies focusing on content regulation. Although the reason for the move is unknown, analyst suggest that the nature of moderation work might contribute to the companies “well-time” exit. Cognizant cut as many as 7,000 jobs due to their exit of content moderation, impacting another 6,000 employees world wide. Cognizant said they would remove 10,000-12,000 employees and “resell and redeploy” about 5,000 of those impacted.” Which was the perfect opportunity for other moderation business to pick up more moderators globally. Company executives said, "Exiting this area will impact an additional approximately 6,000 roles worldwide, though the company intends to work with its partners to explore ways to transition the roles to alternative vendors, thereby reducing the impact to associates”(Mendonca, J, https://colorado.idm.oclc.org/login?url=https://www-proquest-com.colorado.idm.oclc.org/newspapers/cognizant-cut-7000-mid-senior-level-jobs-exit/docview/2310750784/se-2?accountid=14503).

overview.name: Wipro
overview.description: Wipro provides digital data services to companies and works with Facebook to moderate content. Unlike other companies, Wipro claims that you should moderate content because “it increases your connect with users” and that moderating content “increases your bran value and boosys marketing campaigns.” They believe in the balance between Al and an effective team of moderatos to keep “our trusted internet safe and relevant” (https://www.wipro.com/blogs/debjit-maitra/the-need-for-content-moderation/). Wipro has developed a moderation system that legerages Al and ML along with technologies like Blockchaon and crowdsourcing, to help combat fake content. They place their content moderators to regulate specific goes, making it a safer environment and less culturally sensitive content. According to Wipro their vision is to build a content moderation model that has a “right set of technologies – with a proactive, preemptive approach, and right skilled humans - with innate cultural intelligence, extremely skilled in psychological aspects and located strategically, will reduce the complexities involved in the process and contribute to a safer internet ecosystem” (https://www.wipro.com/business-process/content-moderation-a-perspective-on-the-present-and-future-implications/).

overview.description: Wipro provides digital data services to companies and works with Facebook to moderate content. Unlike other companies, Wipro claims that you should moderate content because “it increases your connect with users” and that moderating content “increases your bran value and boosys marketing campaigns.” They believe in the balance between Al and an effective team of moderatos to keep “our trusted internet safe and relevant” (https://www.wipro.com/blogs/debjit-maitra/the-need-for-content-moderation/). Wipro has developed a moderation system that legerages Al and ML along with technologies like Blockchaon and crowdsourcing, to help combat fake content. They place their content moderators to regulate specific goes, making it a safer environment and less culturally sensitive content. According to Wipro their vision is to build a content moderation model that has a “right set of technologies – with a proactive, preemptive approach, and right skilled humans - with innate cultural intelligence, extremely skilled in psychological aspects and located strategically, will reduce the complexities involved in the process and contribute to a safer internet ecosystem” (https://www.wipro.com/business-process/content-moderation-a-perspective-on-the-present-and-future-implications/).

overview.name: Hays
overview.description: Hays Requiting Experts Worldwide is an outsourcing firm Facebook uses to Employ content motors. They offer a Recruitment process outsourcing service that enables the business to transfer all or part of your permanent recruitment and staffing supplier management. The Hays website provides outsourcing services to “help organizations thrive,” the website states, “The management of candidates from multiple channels: internal, referral, speculative, direct, agency – within a single process.” This company has many companies worldwide. They offer a Managed Service Programme service which allows companies to pick the “right talent, at the right time and cost, regardless of source.” This service “offers full visibility and control of your contingent workforce and suppliers.” Hays runs operations in 33 countries worldwide, with 20 offices in North America and 12 in the US. Hays was established in Lodo in 1968, and the last year has placed 220,00 workers into contract assignments and 63,000 into full-time positions. There was not much content on Hays, and its involvement with Facebook.

overview.name: Voxpro acquired by Telus International
overview.description: Voxpro Limited is a private company that supplies multilingual customer service and technical support services. In 2017 TELUS International is a global business outsourcing firm that has acquired Voxpro; the company says they have locations in the U.S., Romania, Ireland, and the Philippians. Voxpro-- powered by TELUS international. Big clients listed in the International Directory of Company Histories include Airbnb, Google, and Nest Labs. In one of Voxpro's job offerings on Remote Weekly, the job description mentions that a content moderator for social media will be "supporting a popular social media platform known for short videos." They describe how the positions will start working from home then may transition to an onsite center with time. Voxpro reformed their company in 2005 to introduce a five-year plan to focus on call answering and business process outsourcing. Voxpro focuses on making their business service multilingual instead of focusing on the local economy. Voxpro supports 35 languages, and significant clients say that they consider Voxpro "a premium international location and a good place to do business." Google was Voxpro's first client, and shortly after, Voxpro landed work with U.S companies that were entering international markets in places such as Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. Voxpro provides TELUS international with additional diversity and flexibility in meeting the needs of marketplace disruptors. Voxpro has 3 locations in Cork, Dublin, and San Francisco, but TELUS has many more globally.

Voxpro supports 35 languages, and significant clients say that they consider Voxpro "a premium international location and a good place to do business." Google was Voxpro's first client, and shortly after, Voxpro landed work with U.S companies that were entering international markets in places such as Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. Voxpro provides TELUS international with additional diversity and flexibility in meeting the needs of marketplace disruptors. Voxpro has 3 locations in Cork, Dublin, and San Francisco, but TELUS has many more globally.

overview.name: Majorel
overview.description: Majorel provides ontent moderation (BPO) for Facebook, with 500 other clients globally. This new business has over 58,000 employees in 28 different countries across the world in 36 languages. Majorel is enormous in the content moderation industry and strives to "Ensuring User-Generated content on my platform is safe and complaint," says the Majorel website (https://www.majorel.com/how-we-can-help/ensuring-user-generated-content-on-my-platform-is-safe-and-compliant/). The website and other sources only list three office locations, although the company is global. Majorel was launched by Bertelsmann and Saham's in 2019, Majorel has their leading markets in Europe, Africa, and the Middle East. The rebranding of Arvato and the other companies such as Phone Group, Ecco Outsourcing, and Pioneers Outsourcing was how Majorel first came to be. The company plans to invest in spreading their companies geography and services heavily. This company started in 2019 after the companies joined together; Bertelsmann said, "The formation of Majorel came about in response to seismic changes that are happening in the customer experience industry, driven by the rapidly evolving digital landscape." They explain, "we combine latest artificial intelligence (AI) technology and our extensive network of experienced reviewers to help you moderate content at scale." They help all website owners ensure that their platform content is not "attracting extremist and illegal content." They also moderate advertisements to ensure that they are trustworthy. The moderate all inappropriate content at any lounges source with help with their Al based technology. The website explains, "Working hand-in-hand with the AI, our expert content reviewers apply contextual understanding, cultural affinity and legal knowledge before creating posts according to your guidelines or passing them on to your in-house team or respective authorities, if needed." When exploring the content moderation services in their website, they are actively recruiting moderators, the sources says "wherever you are, whatever your culture, whatever your global reach or local differences, we speak your language." The company is pursuing growth in the content moderation industry and is planning on extending to new regions globally. Major also works together with Arvato, another outsourcing firm that outsources Facebook. Majorel, CEO of North America, said that "We look forward to helping North American companies expand into new territories, with an emphasis on culture and the importance it has on a global customer service strategy. We see today's rapidly changing world as an opportunity to innovate using both people and technology to create the best customer experience possible for our clients" (https://www.destinationcrm.com/Articles/CRM-News/CRM-Across-the-Wire/New-Company-Majorel-Launches-130055.aspx). The company continues to focus on global expansion with little to no information where these offices are located. This company intends to invest several million dollars into the business they started with 1.2 billion euros and wants to implement automated technology in half of their call center interactions by 2027.

overview.name: censorship
overview.description: This is the result of the online privacy and security company Surfshark's study of 185 nations. Currently, about three percent of the countries surveyed block access to social media and communication apps - all of them are in Asia. In China, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Iran, it is mainly foreign social networks such as Twitter and Facebook that are blocked

overview.name: data leaks
overview.description: 533 million users' phone numbers and personal data have been leaked online because of a cyber attack and facebook is recieving lots of back lash for it and alot of peoples information is out there to the public and facebook needs to do something to fix it and gain users trust back.

overview.name: passwork protection
overview.description: The passwords of around 600 million facebook users were accessible by aorund 20,000 facebook employees, and contained within plain text. This is mainly impacting users of Facebook Lite, users in areas with poorer connection that is more sparsely dispersed. This is example is one in a long line of users who are prone to data breaches from several security flaws.

overview.name: tracking
overview.description: Facebook is under fire for giving off personal information of its users to advertisers. overview.name: ONAVO
overview.description: Facebook's ONAVO VPN is advertised to Facebook's users as a way to protect themselves from breaches. In reality, the program is used to even further mine personal data and sell it elsewhere.

overview.name: phone records
